author: .fjl
content:
I think it still makes sense to have it, and let me explain why. In the agreement that was reached, we said that clients are allowed to delete specifically the pre-merge history. More recent is kept. The idea to use eth/69 as a 'marker' for pruned mode was floated in ACD, but it was later rejected by all clients. So eth/69    implementation doesn't mean the client has no history.

The general history storage model is one where we assume the client has all recent history up to some point, and either 

- none before
- some history before, but it's not specified which 

The eth protocol as proposed implements exactly the baseline assumption and nothing else. For the purpose of eth protocol, you only want to sync recent history back to the merge (or another point for testnets) and then you need to get the rest somewhere else, if you want it.
